Alert

An alert is used to notify the user of important changes or conditions in the application. Use this if you need to communicate to users in a prominent way.

Alerts should not be used to display form validation errors. Instead use the FormField component to display an error associated with a specific input field. Alerts can be used, once a form has been submitted, to display an error that pertains to the entire form, or at least is not tied to any specific field.

Hey, it actually worked!
Just so you know...
I've got a bad feeling about this...
Meeee-Maaaaw! Meeee-Maaaaw! Meeee-Maaaaw!
<>
  <Alert severity="success">Hey, it actually worked!</Alert>
  <Alert severity="info">Just so you know...</Alert>
  <Alert severity="warning">I've got a bad feeling about this...</Alert>
  <Alert severity="error">Meeee-Maaaaw! Meeee-Maaaaw! Meeee-Maaaaw!</Alert>
  <Alert severity="success" when={false}>
    This should not be visible.
  </Alert>
</>

The when={condition} property can be used to prevent the alert from being shown. Since alerts are often displayed conditionally, depending on whether there is a current error condition, this removes the need to surround the alert with an extra layer of conditional logic.

Alert properties

Checkboxes accept all of the standard properties for an HTML checkbox element. The only additional attribute is the "indeterminate" option:

NameDescriptionType
severityIndicates the severity (and thus, the color scheme) of the alert.
  • success
  • info
  • warning
  • error
whenAn optional property which can be used to conditionally hide the alert. If not present, the alert will always be shown.boolean
